description: Absolutely amazing. If you come to San Francisco and miss this gem of a restaurant then you have missed an opportunity of a lifetime to try so many amazing foods. I would strongly recommend Khai to anyone who is looking for a unique dining experience. I will most differently return.
author: Michael F.

description: So I set up a reservation for 6, invited business clients. Going to be a fun great evening. Then the restaurant called and confirmed, then 3 days later they called and told me that they had overbooked and I needed to come another night. So be very careful if you think you have reservations, their system seems very disorganized. I haven't been ever been disinvited to a restaurant that I have had reservations at.
author: Horace L.

description: I came here with my family for my birthday and we are very happy we did! I've eaten Vietnamese my entire life, but this opened my eyes to just how exquisite the cuisine could be. The fixed ten course meal paired beautifully with the selected wines in the flight. My favorite courses were the vermicelli with butter fish in tumeric sauce, beef tartar with shrimp crackers, and Chef Khai's signaure durian wrapped in banh cuon in a coconut and raspberry sauce. Before every dish was served, Chef Khai would explain the dish and his inspiration behind the flavors. Highly recommend for delicious food and a great dining experience.
author: Tilly N.

description:
The wife and I had the privilege of dining here New Years Eve. The food was incredible and having Chef Khai come out and explain each dish added that extra touch which wasn't really necessary, but appreciated nonetheless.  My favorite dish was the pork belly rice noodle with tomato soup. If reminded me of a very well made Bun Ryu soup.  The most unexpected dish was the signature desert which had durian mixed in with coconut, ginger and pomegranate. Knowing how odd this particular fruit tastes, I was pleasantly surprised at how well the desert tasted and how well it was executed. Well done!  

In short, if you're looking for a new culinary experience with a southeast Asian twist, Khai is most definitely worth a try. 

(I'm only giving 4 starts for now since I know that Chef Khai is only just beginning to spread his wings with his latest creation... We look forward to returning in a few months to see how  much his creation will have grown.)
author: Ryan D.

description:
As of this writing, there is little I can add that does not echo both the praises and the criticisms of Khai Vietnamese Noveau. In short: at its price point, the ambiance is barely passable, the service is average but professional, and the food-- most of it-- is unforgettable. Thus if you are any sort of reasonable, sentient creature, Khai is worth your visit, if for the food alone. 

The restaurant is tucked away among a strip of similarly indistinct businesses, with the looming Zynga building across the street being the easiest landmark to guide you to the vicinity. The interior is dark and cramped, and your view is either the black curtains blocking off the kitchen or said Zynga building outside the window. There is nothing in the restaurant that evokes a personality of any sort; you're eating in, essentially, an emptied out office sprawl. And it feels that way. An atmosphere that is intimate but industrial, lacking character. Basically, it's a pop-up. You would be nearly fooled into believing the night will be unenjoyable. 

And then the tasting menu starts. 

Chef Khai is unpretentious and heartfelt, and it reflects strongly in his wine offerings and his cuisine. Flavors are bold, and each dish provokes a delicate balance of home and haute.Many have described the menu, and perhaps it is easiest to compare the starter and the dessert is to realize the journey you will experience. An opener of a bright jicama salad inspired from Chef Khai's mother that tastes wholly Vietnamese traditional, with the classic pungency of mint, fish sauce, and peanuts with a translucent, chewy white seaweed being the lone surprise; a closing dessert celebrating coconut and durian, with a clever roll of coconut jelly cocooning the delightfully funky durian filling, becoming something different altogether. You'll find a tasting menu that builds and builds, both in daring and in gastronomic intensity. Each course is paced well, spaced with enough time to linger and reflect. Within the ten courses, you will undoubtedly find a dish that will make you pause. For me it was the "tartare," an eye-rolling burst of flavor that was as if I was in a topsy turvy world where the star of ceviche was not fish, but beef. Spread upon a delicate chip, there is savory crunch, a punch of acid, and then indescribable deliciousness. 

Once you find yourself at your seat at Khai's and focus on the experience itself, you'll see glimpses of what Chef Khai has brought back with him during his time away. Enjoy his company, his hospitality, and his food. You will not regret it.
author: H C.

description:
The food was great and the staff was awesome! They explained each dish and they came out at a perfect cadence. My favorites were probably the crab sausage, the lamb, and the durian dessert. Also notable were the seaweed salad (probably the first seaweed salad I've ever really liked), the garlic quail, and the butterfish. The tartar, rice chips, and the ceviche weren't my favorites compared to the others, but they were still great, and the presentation on the rice chips was awesome, which made them worth it. :)

Khai is definitely recommended and a great experience. We'll definitely return when he changes up the menu (to me, tasting menus are all about trying new things).
author: Sean B.

description: Amazing food. Brilliant chef. Hands down best meal I've had in a long time, maybe ever.
author: Raquel L.

description: Amazing food and presentation, generous portions.  It  felt very special to have chef personally come out and describe most of the courses.  Allow 2.5 - 3 hours for dinner.
author: Robin W.

description: Best meal of 2017 and 2016.  Personalized attention, customize meal, 10 courses of delicious amazing Vietnamese food. The owner and chef shared a glass of wine with us and we couldn't be happier to be dining at his restaurant for our last day of vacation. Best night of our trip.
author: Eric G.

description: Absolutely masterful flavor combinations, and probably one of the best meals I've ever had in SF. The multi-course meal was amazing, from the refreshingly crunchy seaweed salad to the smoke lemongrass-lamb, to the *gasp* durian dessert. The chef was very sweet, personable, and had great stories for every dish and how it came to be. I couldn't be more impressed with the ingenious flavor/texture combos experienced during this meal. Had a lovely time here for my birthday (best bf ever). Highly recommended. Although the price seems high initially the amount and quality of the experience will be totally worth it.
author: Marina F.

description: Just Open, every dish is carefully crafted by the iron chef! The set menu is the way to go, great with wines. I love the fish, lamb, soup and dessert! Unbelievable.
author: Wilson C.

description: Amazing! A great dining experience. The chef really blew my mind with out of the world creations and pairings. A must try !
author: John M.

description:
Absolutely amazing dining.  Not a foodie guy; but found each dish to be delicious.  Never had that experience.  Presentation was artistic and flavors delightful.  Chose a Syrah which match the meal perfectly.  Great way to share New Year Eve.  People got to try this place

David2
author: David T.

description: Found Khai a bit overbearing. Food is okay. Some dishes are better than others. Dinner took longer than expected.
author: James K.

description: My husband and I totally enjoyed the 9 course dinner with wine pairing.  Price was good for this type of dining.  Portions were good and adequate.  Chef Khai used a lot of different spices in his dishes.  Each dish was explained by the server.  Chef Khai actually came out from the kitchen, served some dishes and talked to us.  Service was good.  However we would probably not get the wine pairing next time.  We preferred white served first and then graduated to the heavier wine towards the end.  But at Khai they alternated white and red and we don't think the wine actually helped bringing out the flavor of the food.
author: Lily L.

description: Trying very hard but food mediocre, long explanation of simple dishes, overpriced, a black curtain in dining area to hide the kitchen, and when I took a business call and stepped outside not to disturb the other diners the wait staff came outside to tell me the chef could not wait for me and that I should finish the call as I was disrupting the flow!  LOL  I am not making this up.  True.
author: Mariko T.

description: It is not really correct to categorize Khai as a Vietnamese restaurant. While Chef Khai takes full advantage of the flavors and spices of Vietnam, this is no just very good restaurant. It is truly Haute Cuisine. Chef Khai's concept of everything he turns out is beautifully sophisticated. Our starter was a white seaweed salad with just a touch of red onion, a hint of mint and a very delicate citrus vinaigrette. Just wonderful. Since this is a ten course tasting menu I won't go into each one, but some of the highlights were a crab sausage underlain with a slice of watermelon radish and dots of oil infused with pepper and key lime. The flavors worked perfectly together. Another was a salmon ceviche salad with noodles and green apples and a side of tomato and prawn infused soup; out of this world. A perfectly prepared medallion of lamb with Vietnamese spices that I couldn't identify over a lovely eggplant preparation. It ended with a surprising desert of young coconut wrapped around durian with a coconut cream sauce with pomegranate seeds. Lovely. Finally, a cup of lemongrass ginger tea which was not only delicate but also somehow unctuous. Definitely do the wine parings. They are beautifully thought out. Where are the Michelin reviewers?  Get there soon.
author: David M.

description: We were running late to our reservations at 5:30 pm. Roads were blocked off, had to literally hop off our Lyft and walk a few blocks to catch a different ride.  I was going to give up and call to cancel our reservations and willingly lose that $100 fee for cancellations. But the lady on the phone was so sweet and accommodating that she told us to come, they were about to serve the first course and if anything we will just miss the first two courses. We rushed over there and got there just in time for the second course. OMG I'm so happy that I went!!!Vietnamese food to the next level. AND lucky for us they brought out the first course for us to try! Everything was beautifully presented and tasted delicious. My favorites were the foie gras, black cod fish, the lamb, and the durian desert! Chef Khai wasn't there this time but We'll definitely be back! Oh and thank you Miss Chau, great service and we enjoyed our little chats. Great experience here!
author: Lynda T.

description: This is the best meal i've had in years.  Exquisite, original, beautifully presented multi-course dinner.  The atmosphere is warm and friendly, nothing pretentious about it.  Memorable.
author: Renee P.

description: What a culinary experience .  Compliments to Chef Khai.  Didn't know what to expect and left very happy .  He got me to eat eggplant and durian AND like it . So delicious and just the right amount of food for a sampling menu.  Hope the restaurant makes it in this very competitive market in SF
author: MJ C.

description: Fantastic dining experience. 10 courses, not a single one the same, and all devine. Loved every bit of this modern spin on Vietnamese food. Wow!
author: Heather D.

description: Happy to be able to experience some new flavors. First night jitters, slow service, no consistency in the message that came with each dish. Chef was there as was his wife, which Chef gave credit to the appearance of the dishes and praised her assistance. The dishes were inspired by his life in Vietnam. The courses were lovely to look at but do need some work. I believe it will only get better. Chef stated he was interested in providing some ingredients  native to Vietnam to his patrons. Chef was very friendly and the glasses were never empty. Highlights for me include: the seaweed salad, a white seaweed from Vietnam, (needed more acid for me), texture and presentation were great, turmeric fish was just barely cooked (I wish I could just cook fish like it was cooked) and had amazing texture and flavor ( I was lucky my fish still had 3 bones), the quail KFQ was outstanding ( gummy yucca under the quail could have been a more pleasing texture), the lamb (not a lamb fan) was amazing, had a spice from Vietnam, scallion oil and lemongrass powder, so good. Do go, I'm sure the kinks will be worked out.
author: C W.
